Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Remote Ischemic Preconditioning in Reducing Postoperative Cognitive Dysfunction

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants were adults undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) with RIPC.

Intervention.evidence: Eligible participants were adults undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) with RIPC.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy of remote ischemic preconditioning (RIPC) in reducing neurocognitive dysfunction in patients undergoing CPB surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of POCD, assessed up to 12 months postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment were adequately reported in all studies.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for participants and personnel.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Five RCTs with a total of 1,843 participants were included.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: RIPC was not associated with a significant reduction in the incidence of POCD (OR = 0.79, 95% CI = 0.56–1.11) or improvement in cognitive function (OR = 0.80, 95% CI = 0.50–1.27).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.

Funding.evidence: The study received no financial support.
